1.    Executive Summary
1.1.     Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The management of Fresh Express is committed to maintaining a safe work environment.  A Safety and Security Manager has been assigned to ensure that safe practices are followed in the specification and operation of systems involving hazardous chemicals.  This site has developed and trained a Quick Response Team to ensure rapid and appropriate response to ammonia emergencies.  The site has specific and written evacuation, reporting, and response procedures in place to protect Fresh Express employees, the public, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release. 

1.2.          Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
The Fresh Express plant covered by this RMP is located at 2370 W. Warrior Trail, Grand Prairie, Texas. The facility receives lettuce and other produce to be processed, packaged for consumer use in various salad mixes, set for short-term storage, and transported and distributed from this site.

The regulated substance is anhydrous ammonia.  One fixed ammonia refrigeration system is used for refrigerating produce at various temperatures. The total charge to this refrigeration system is 15,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  

1.3.          Release Scenarios
The worst-case release scenario considered for this process is a release of the volume of the single High Pressure Receiver (a maximum of (15,000 lbs)[1].  No administrative controls and mitigation measures were considered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst-case scenario is 0.7 miles.

The alternative release scenario considered for this process is a release of ammonia through the pressure relief device caused by over pressurization of ammonia in the High Pressure Receiver (HPR).  The total volume of the refrigeration system Â¿ 15,000 lbs of ammonia Â¿ was used for the release calculations.  No administrative controls o

r mitigation measures were considered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the alternative release scenario is 0.4 mile.

1.4.     Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Prevention of accidental ammonia release at Fresh Express is accomplished through sound industry practice in the original ammonia refrigeration system design and construction, the specification and review of system modifications, and the day-to-day operation and maintenance of the system.  

This includes:

Â·        Compliance with industry standards and codes in effect at the time of initial construction and modification

Â·        Performance of a thorough Process Hazard Analyses (PHAÂ¿s) at least once every five years using accurate Process Safety Information

Â·        Implementation of Operating Procedures which have been reviewed by PHA

Â·        Appropriate initial and refresher training of system operations and maintenance personnel  

Â·        Performance of preventive and corrective maintenance according to system component manufacturer recommendations and pursuant to site wide hazardous energy lockout and hot work permit programs

Â·        Application of established auditing, inspection, and pre-start-up review protocols

Â·        Use of qualified contractors for work on the system

The detailed Ammonia System Release Prevention Program is contained in a supporting document (revised and updated July, 2010) that is maintained by the siteÂ¿s Safety Manager.

1.5.          Five-year Accident History
Between December, 2004 (the previous revalidation of the site program) and the present, no ammonia releases resulted in onsite or off-site injuries, deaths, or property damage, or off-site environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place. However, the following ammonia-related incident occurred:

 

6/11/06 Â¿ During routine maintenance, an electrical contractor isolated

power to the ammonia condensers.  During this time, the compressors continued to operate, increasing the ammonia pressure in the condensers.  The pressure increased to 230psig which caused three pressure relief devices (PRVÂ¿s) to lift.  This resulted in a release of 78 lbs of ammonia, aggregate, to the atmosphere.  Plant personnel were able to immediately respond to the situation.  Corrective actions were completed and the system was placed back online within one day.

1.6.     Emergency Response Program
Fresh Express has developed an Emergency Planning and Response document to ensure adequate preparedness with rapid and appropriate response to ammonia release emergencies.  The plan is maintained at the siteÂ¿s Safety Manager and is reviewed annually.  The document describes outside agency notification procedures in the event of an ammonia release, provides detailed evacuation procedures, and includes response procedures for the mitigation of ammonia releases. 

The site has an Ammonia Quick Response Team trained to use the Incident Command System organizational framework.  This is also described in detail in the planning document.

3.    Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) Summary
The OCA for the system was reviewed during the Revalidation PHA in May 2010. The PHA team determined that the existing scenarios continued to be valid for the system. Therefore the OCA has been included, unchanged except for minor editorial changes, in this updated RMP/PSM document.

3.1.          Facility Description and Site Layout
The Fresh Express facility located at 2370 W. Warrior Trail, Grand Prairie, Texas prepares and packages prepared salads.  Various types of fruits and vegetables (tomatoes, onions, grapes, apples, oranges, lettuce, cabbage, spinach, carrots and broccoli) are delivered to the facility, where they are washed, processed, dried, packaged and stored for shipment. 

A stationary anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system is used for room cooling and process water chilling.  This system is depicted on the block flow diagram in Figure 5-1.  The total anhydrous ammonia charge to the system is 15,000 pounds.  This ammonia refrigeration system is the only process at this site to which the RMP requirements are applicable.

The site includes a large Main Processing Building which includes administrative offices; the Refrigeration Engine Room; small support buildings; the shipping and receiving areas; and employee and visitor parking lots. Some refrigeration equipment and piping are located outdoors.  A site plan is presented as Attachment 1.

The site is located 17 miles southwest of Dallas, Texas near the intersection of Arkansas Lane and South Great Southwest Parkway, in Grand Prairie.  The facility is surrounded by residential and commercial areas.  Grand Prairie Municipal Airport lies to the west of the Fresh Express property.  

Because the ammonia refrigeration system is considered a Program 3 process, one worst-case release scenario and an alternative release scenario have been analyz

ed for this RMP. 

3.2.          OCA Methodology
The analyses herein follow the requirements specified by the Federal RMP (40 CFR 68.22). The method follows Chapter 4 of the EPA/CEPPO Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration dated May 2000. LandViewÂ®6 software application was used to map the offsite consequence analysis (OCA) for the Worst-Case and Alternative Release scenarios. In addition, LandViewÂ®6 was used for demographic information, jurisdictional entities, detailed topological features.

 

3.3.     Release Scenarios
3.3.1.           Worst-Case Release Scenario Analysis
Since the Fresh Express ammonia refrigeration system is considered an RMP Program 3 process, the worst-case release scenario was identified as that which was estimated to create the greatest distance in any direction to the toxic endpoint for ammonia.  The worst-case release quantity was defined as the greatest amount potentially held in a single vessel location (i.e., 15,000 pounds in the High Pressure Receiver). No mitigating controls were assumed.

Pursuant to the Environmental Protection Agency / Chemical Emergency Preparedness and Prevention OfficeÂ¿s (EPA/CEPPOÂ¿s) Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration, the meteorological and site specific variables assumed for the analysis are as follows:

Release Rate - Ammonia is a liquid under pressure in this part of the refrigeration system.  The guidance specifies the release rate as the quantity released as a gas over 10 minutes.  This rapid release of ammonia is an airborne mixture of vapor and droplets.  Since the High Pressure Receiver (HPR) is located outdoors, all the vapor and droplets are assumed to remain airborne.  The release rate is calculated as follows:

QR = Q/10

Where:       QR = Release Rate (lbs/min)

                 Q = Quantity Released (lbs)

Using our scenario criteria:

QR = 15,000 lbs / 10 min  = 1,500 lbs/min (unmitigated)

Distance to the Toxic Endpoint - Based on the estimated worst-case release rate of 1500 lbs/min, RMP*Comp V 1.07 shows the distance to the toxic endpoint at 0.7 miles from the single High Pressure Receiver.  The Â¿urbanÂ¿ distance was used, since there are buildings in the immediate area.

See 3.6 for a description and enumeration of the receptors within this distance.

3.3.2.           Alternative Release Scenario Analysis
Pursuant to RMP regulations, the alternative release scenario was identified as that which is more likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario, and that which will reach an endpoint offsite.  The alternative release scenario used meteorological conditions more representative of the site than those used for the worst case.  

The alternative release scenarios considered both the five-year accident history and the results of the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study conducted at Fresh Express on May 6, 2010.  When these other scenarios were evaluated, the end results were no worse than the last analysis completed in December 2004. As a result, the selected Alternative Release Scenario remains unchanged.  

The scenario chosen is a lifted pressure relief device that has lifted due to the high pressure receiver exceeding 250 psig.  It is assumed that the entire volume of the system

will be released.  The flow through the pressure relief device is calculated to be 1417 lbs per minute.  No mitigating controls were assumed.

3.6.          Offsite Impacts
As required by the regulations, Fresh

Express has estimated the populations that fall within the circle defined by the distance to toxic endpoints for both the worst-case and alternative release scenarios.

3.6.1.           Residential Populations
The LandViewÂ®6 desktop mapping program was used to pinpoint the Fresh Express facility and estimate populations within the release scenario radius.  Using the population estimator within the LandViewÂ®6 program, it was determined by the Block Group Proration method that approximately 3,215 people (1,132 households) reside within the 0.7-mile radius of the worst-case release scenario.  The same population estimator was used to determine that there are 874 people (271 households) residing within the 0.4-mile radius of the alternative release scenario.

A LandViewÂ®6 map depicting the worst-case and alternative release vapor cloud radii is included in 3.5.

3.6.2.           Other Public Receptors
In addition to residences, public receptors that must be noted in the RMP are schools, hospitals, long-term health care and child day care facilities, prisons, public recreational areas, and major commercial or industrial areas.  Based on review of the LandViewÂ®6 program data and Google Maps (http://maps.google.com), there are three (3) churches, two (2) heliports, one (1) school, one (1) airport.  Within the alternative release scenario radius, there is one (1) school and one (1) church.

3.6.3.           Environmental Receptors
Environmental receptors that must be noted in the RMP are natural areas, such as national or state parks, forests or monuments; wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges or areas; and Federal wilderness areas.  None of these types of receptors appear to be located within the worst-case or alternative release scenario circles.

6.    Emergency Response Program Summary
Fresh Express has prepared an Ammonia Refrigeration System Emergency Planning and Response Document.  The date of the most recent review and update of this plan was in [mmmm, dddd, yyyy].  The date of the most recent emergency response training for the Ammonia Emergency Response team was in [mmmm yyyy].

The written plan includes the following information as required by the RMP:

Â·      Specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of ammonia;

Â·      Procedures for informing the public and local agencies responsible for responding to accidental releases; and

Â·      Information on emergency health care.

The primary local emergency response agency with which the Emergen

cy Plan is coordinated is the Grand Prairie Fire Department.  Their emergency telephone number is 9-1-1.  The non-emergency telephone number is 972.237.8300.

6.1.          Plan Overview
If an ammonia release poses a potential safety or health hazard to Fresh Express employees or the public, the Fresh Express Safety and Security Manager or Incident Commander will contact the Grand Prairie Fire Department and the appropriate medical care provider. Notification of other agencies will be made if the release quantity exceeds the reporting threshold.  Evacuation of the facility in the event of an ammonia release follows the evacuation procedures for other types of emergencies.  Employees are drilled in evacuation procedures annually.  The Fresh Express ERT will not attempt to remove personnel from areas that might expose ERT members to hazardous levels of ammonia.  Persons who can move to uncontaminated areas will receive basic first aid/CPR and care from the ERT until the Grand Prairie Fire Department Emergency Medical Service (EMS) arrives.  An MSDS will be provided to the EMS accompanying the victim to the hospital.
